column2: Clinton seen going toe-to-toe with Putin	"

column1: By Warren Strobel and Matt Spetalnick
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON When Hillary Clinton attended her first major White House meeting on Russia in February 2009
column2: the new secretary of state insisted that she wanted to play a leading role in President Barack Obama's effort to ""reset"" U.S. relations with Moscow.But while Clinton became implementer-in-chief for one of Obama's signature first-term initiatives
column3: she was consistently more skeptical than most of his top aides about how far Russian leader Vladimir Putin was prepared to go in turning the page
column4: according to current and former U.S. officials.That stance is indicative of how she would go about dealing with Moscow if she is elected U.S. president on Nov. 8
column5: aides to both Clinton and Obama told Reuters.With U.S. relations with Moscow already plumbing post-Cold War lows
column6: the aides and veteran Russia watchers said she would likely take a harder line than Obama or Republican nominee Donald Trump
column7: who has praised Putin as a strong leader.Dealing with Putin
column8: who is flexing his geopolitical muscle from Ukraine to Syria to cyberspace
column9: will be among Clinton's biggest foreign policy challenges -- one made more daunting by the personal bad blood between them.Jake Sullivan
column10: a former top State Department aide and now senior Clinton campaign advisor
column11: said Clinton could consider the shipping of lethal arms to Ukraine government forces and the creation of no-fly or safe zones in Syria. Obama has rejected both ideas.While such moves could further stoke tensions and might even face resistance from some U.S. allies
column12: Sullivan said in an interview with Reuters that Clinton could manage ties with Russia effectively because Putin would ""respect her as U.S. president
column15: her predictability.""According to current and former Clinton advisers
column16: she could consider other policy moves such as stiffer sanctions against Russia over Ukraine and doing more to wean Russia's neighbors off reliance on Moscow's energy supplies.Russia is watching warily.""She is not perceived by many people as the Kremlin's preferred candidate
column18: director general of the Russian International Affairs Council
column19: a think tank close to the Russian Foreign Ministry.""Many here believe that she would be tougher on Russia than Obama
column20: he said. Clinton's first fence-mending effort in March 2009 was not so much a show of strength than of diplomatic clumsiness. She handed Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov a red button that was supposed to have the word ""reset"" on it. Instead
column21: it was labeled with the Russian word meaning ""overcharged.""Clinton's distrust of Putin deepened
column22: mirrored by his growing list of grievances against her.By the time she prepared to leave the State Department in early 2013
column24: she wrote at least two confidential memos to Obama urging a more hard-nosed approach. At the time
column25: many in the president's inner circle were not convinced the reset had run its course

column1: Since Clinton's departure
column2: Putin has reasserted Russia on the world stage
column3: seizing Ukraine's Crimea region and intervening militarily in Syria's civil war. U.S. officials have linked the hacking of Democratic Party computers to the Russian government - which the Kremlin denies.""NOT AS IF SHE WENT GRUMPILY""

column1: Like most national security policies under Obama
column2: the attempt to ""reset"" U.S.-Russian relations was managed from the White House by the president himself
column3: along with aides from his 2008 campaign
column4: including Russia specialist Michael McFaul.""No one should pretend that this wasn't an Obama-driven policy
column5: said Philip Gordon
column6: Clinton's top Europe adviser at the State Department. ""But it's also not as if she went grumpily to the table and was told by the president 'you're doing it' ... She thought it had logic.""McFaul
column7: who later became ambassador to Russia
column8: said in an interview that from the first White House meeting on Russia in early 2009 Clinton was skeptical of the prospects for transforming U.S.-Russian relations in a way that ""some of us aspired to back then."" Two other officials backed up his account.

column1: The first fruits of the reset were promising.Putin had - temporarily
column2: it turned out - stepped down as   president
column3: with the younger
column4: reform-minded Dmitry Medvedev in his place.Obama and Medvedev signed a new strategic nuclear arms control pact
column5: cooperated to sanction Iran for its nuclear program and agreed to let U.S. troops and equipment transit Russia to support a American military ""surge"" in Afghanistan. But after little more than two years
column6: the ""reset"" ran out of steam. By mid-2011
column7: it was clear that Putin was returning to the presidency.A DECADE OF BROADSIDES

column1: Clinton first met Putin at his residence outside Moscow in March 2010. She persuaded him to back tougher U.N. sanctions on Iran
column2: according to two people with knowledge of the session.

column1: In front of the TV cameras
column2: however
column3: Putin railed against U.S. trade and economic policies as Clinton watched.Clinton and Putin have been exchanging broadsides for nearly a decade.Putin
column4: a former KGB agent
column5: ""doesn't have a soul
column6: Clinton quipped on the eve of the 2008 New Hampshire presidential primary
column7: riffing off of President George W. Bush's comment seven years earlier that he had looked into Putin's eyes and seen his soul.The Russian leader retorted: ""At a minimum
column8: a head of state should have a head.""A U.S. official who was involved in Russia policymaking said Clinton sometimes chose her words poorly
column9: inflaming Russian resentment over its perceived post-Cold War humiliation
column10: a nationalist strain that Putin has long used to his advantage. ""She played into that
column12: who requested anonymity. The most serious rift of Clinton's tenure occurred in late 2011
column13: as crowds filled the streets of Russian cities protesting parliamentary elections marred by allegations of voting fraud.Clinton
column14: in a statement approved by the White House
column15: called the election ""neither free nor fair."" Putin
column16: who was preparing to retake the presidency
column17: accused her of trying to foment a new Russian revolution. A steady slide in contacts between Clinton and the Russian leadership and in overall relations followed.""Secretary Clinton's views on Russia were always a little harder-edged than President Obama's
column19: Obama's first ambassador to Moscow. That partly reflected a ""splitting up of responsibilities
column20: he said. Obama cooperated with Medvedev; Clinton grappled with Lavrov and Putin.Some Russia watchers say Clinton's record was mixed.""The reset was the right approach
column22: former Russia adviser under Bush's Republican administration. But he faulted Clinton and Obama's team for not doing more to ""actively reach out to Putin and open lines of communication."" (Additional reporting by Andrew Osborn in Moscow. Editing by John Walcott and Stuart Grudgings)"	['Sullivan'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-un-idUSKCN11Q0BS	Clinton
column2: Trump vie for world leaders' attention in New York	"

column1: By James Oliphant
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK With national security again a major U.S. election issue after bombings in New York and New Jersey
column2: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump sought to burnish their foreign-policy credentials on Monday by meeting world leaders at the United Nations.For Clinton
column3: the Democratic presidential nominee
column4: it was a return to a role she knows well after she served as President Barack Obama's secretary of state for four years.Trump
column5: the Republican nominee
column6: is a newcomer to the global stage who is hurriedly trying to play catch-up. In rapid succession
column7: Clinton met briefly with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe
column9: and then Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko.Trump also met Sisi minutes after the Egyptian leader spoke with Clinton in the same Manhattan hotel.The meetings came on a day that started with Clinton suggesting Trump's harsh rhetoric toward Muslims aids the Islamic State militant group's recruiting efforts. Trump pushed back
column10: arguing the United States was less safe as a result of Obama and Clinton's policies.

column1: Security questions arose in each of Monday's bilateral sessions
column2: which took place as world leaders gathered for the U.N. General Assembly
column3: with Clinton and Abe discussing concerns over North Korea and maritime issues involving China. Clinton and Trump both spoke with Sisi about working more closely with Egypt to combat the Islamic State threat. Trump's campaign released a statement saying that Trump ""highlighted how Egypt and the U.S. share a common enemy and the importance of working together in defeating radical Islamic terrorism.""

column1: With Clinton
column2: Sisi also discussed his goal of moving Egypt toward ""a new civil society
column3: a new modern country that upholds the rule of law and respects human rights and liberties."" Clinton and Poroshenko addressed Russian incursions into Ukrainian territory. Clinton started the session by saying Ukraine faces ""very real problems and threats from Russian aggression"" and that she was ""anxious to know how we can be supportive."" The session also resonated because of Trump's praise of Russian President Vladimir Putin earlier this month. Trump called Putin a stronger leader than Obama
column4: rattling both Democrats and Republicans in Washington.

column1: The evening was not without drama
column2: starting with Clinton's motorcade zooming through packed New York streets at rush hour and then quickly rushing from hotel to hotel.Trump also tried to bolster his foreign policy credentials last month when he went to Mexico to meet President Enrique Pena Nieto
column3: but both sides ended up disagreeing about whether who would pay to build a border wall had been discussed. Clinton called that episode an ""embarrassing international incident."" (Reporting by James Oliphant; Additional reporting by Yara Bayoumy and Emily Flitter; Editing by Paul Tait)"	['Paul'

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-machines-idUSKCN11Q0EU	Despite flaws
column2: paperless voting machines remain widespread in the U.S.	"

column1: By Andy Sullivan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON One in four registered voters in the United States live in areas that will use electronic voting machines that do not produce a paper backup in the November presidential election despite concerns that they are vulnerable to tampering and malfunctions
column2: according to a Reuters analysis.The lack of a paper trail makes it impossible to independently verify that the aging touch-screen systems are accurate
column3: security experts say
column4: in a year when suspected Russian hackers have penetrated political groups and state voting systems and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has said the election may be ""rigged."" Election officials insist the machines are reliable
column5: but security experts say they are riddled with bugs and security holes that can result in votes being recorded incorrectly. A Reuters analysis of data from the U.S. Census Bureau
column6: the Election Assistance Commission and the Verified Voting Foundation watchdog group found that 44 million registered voters
column7: accounting for 25 percent of the total
column8: live in jurisdictions that rely on paperless systems
column9: including millions in contested states such as Georgia
column10: Pennsylvania and Virginia. The picture has improved gradually since the 2008 presidential election
column11: when 31 percent of U.S. voters lived in areas that used paperless touch-screen systems. In 2012
column12: 27 percent lived in jurisdictions that used paperless systems. ""Clearly we still have a long way to go to ensure that all Americans have access to a form of voting technology they can trust
column14: a University of Michigan computer-science professor who has helped to uncover security flaws on touch-screen systems.(Graphic showing different types of voting systems across the U.S. -- tmsnrt.rs/2cZiKQ5)Most of these machines are nearing the end of their expected life span
column15: making them more vulnerable to problems. And Congress has not authorized money for upgrades since 2002
column16: just after the disputed 2000 presidential recount battle in Florida highlighted flaws in aging punch-card and lever-voting systems.    In some states
column17: a divide has emerged between poorer areas that continue to use paperless touch-screen systems and wealthier areas that have bought new optical scan systems that process paper ballots
column18: which many experts say are a better way to ensure accurate elections.

column1: In Virginia
column2: for example
column3: counties that still use touch-screen systems have a poverty rate of 23 percent
column4: while those that have switched to optical-scan systems have an average poverty rate of 11 percent.""I would have liked to have had the new machines
column5: but the county says we don't have the money
column6: said Patsy Burchett
column7: the top election official in rural Lee County
column8: which has been hit hard by the decline of the coal and tobacco industries and is the poorest county in the state. ""These machines are on their last legs

column1: U.S. election officials have known about the shortcomings of touch-screen systems since shortly after they were widely adopted in the early 2000s
column2: when researchers showed that vote results could be manipulated with tools as simple as a magnet and a Palm Pilot-style handheld device.The systems have produced questionable results in some elections. In Florida
column3: more than 18
column4: 000 iVotronic machines did not record a vote in a 2006 congressional race in which the margin of victory was less than 400 votes. In Fairfax County
column5: Virginia
column6: electronic machines subtracted one vote for every hundred cast for one candidate in a 2003 school-board race. More than 4
column7: 400 electronic ballots in Carteret County
column9: were lost and never recovered in the 2004 presidential election.Since 2008
column10: states such as Maryland have traded in their touch-screen machines for optical-scan systems. Others like California and Ohio have added printers to their touch-screen machines which produce a backup paper trail
column11: while Washington and Colorado moved to mail-in ballots. Absentee balloting is also cutting into the use of paperless systems. In 2012
column13: roughly 1 in 10 voters who lived in areas that used paperless systems cast absentee ballots. Election officials say the touch-screen machines that remain in use are more secure now than they were a decade ago whether they are fitted with printers or not
column14: thanks to extensive testing and better poll-worker training. They say that a hacking incident is unlikely because the machines are not connected to the Internet. ""Voters should have confidence in whatever systems are being used in their jurisdiction because election officials have taken the necessary steps to secure these systems and ensure the integrity of the process
column16: a commissioner with the U.S. Election Assistance Commission.

column1: Although there has so far been no confirmed major incident of U.S. voting machines being hacked
column2: security experts say that those aiming to manipulate votes could spread a virus through memory cards
column3: with no Internet connection needed. The best way to stop that is to switch to paper-based systems
column4: they say.With 55 percent of all U.S. registered voters living in areas that use systems that are no longer in production
column5: according to the Reuters analysis
column6: election officials must rely on a dwindling supply of spare parts.Virginia Beach
column7: Virginia
column9: pulled 32 of its 820 Accuvote TSX touch-screen machines in a 2014 election after residents complained that the machines were registering votes for candidates they didn't support. The city has since purchased a new optical-scan system.Lacking fresh federal funds
column10: some states have opted to upgrade on their own. Louisiana aims to switch to an iPad-based system by 2019
column13: are designing systems from scratch.Others see no reason to switch. In Georgia
column14: Secretary of State Brian Kemp said he hasn't asked the state legislature for money to replace its fleet of paperless AccuVote TS touch-screen machines.""It's working just fine and all these so-called experts that are making these accusations about our system haven't seen it
column15: he said. (Additional reporting by Dustin Volz; editing by Stuart Grudgings)"	['Sullivan'

| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe met U.S. Presidential candidate Hillary Clinton on Monday and stressed it was important for the United States to ratify the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal that she opposes
column2: Japanese officials said.Abe and Clinton met for about 15 minutes at Abe's hotel in New York
column3: where he is attending the United Nations General Assembly

column7: who spoke on condition of anonymity. The pact has been agreed
column8: but not ratified by the United States or Japan.Clinton
column9: the Democratic candidate in the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election
column11: which is unpopular with labor unions and environmental groups
column12: although she championed it while serving as secretary of state.In a speech to U.S. business leaders in New York on Monday

column14: which comes in response to China's rise.

column1: Through the TPP
column2: the U.S. can make clear its commitment to playing a leadership role in the growing Asia-Pacific
column3: he said.""Japan and the U.S. must each obtain domestic approval of the TPP as soon as possible
column4: Abe said. ""Success or failure will sway the direction of the global free trade system
column5: and the strategic environment in the Asia-Pacific.""Abe said he would pursue TPP approval at an upcoming session of Japan's parliament.

column1: Japan will spare no effort
column2: and we count on the U.S. to do the same

column1: The TPP has been pilloried by both Republican and Democratic candidates.Republicans traditionally have backed free trade deals

column1: NEW YORK U.S. President Barack Obama and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang agreed on Monday to step up cooperation in the United Nations Security Council and in law-enforcement channels after North Korea's fifth nuclear test
column2: the White House said.China and the United States are also targeting the finances of Liaoning Hongxiang Industrial
column3: a Chinese conglomerate headed by a Communist Party cadre
column4: that the Obama administration thinks has a role in assisting North Korea's nuclear program
column5: the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.U.N. diplomats say the two countries have started discussions on a possible U.N. sanctions resolution in response to the nuclear test earlier this month
column6: but Beijing has not said directly whether it will support tougher steps against North Korea.Obama met Li on the sidelines of the annual United Nations General Assembly session in New York.""Both leaders condemned North Korea's September 9 nuclear test and resolved to strengthen coordination in achieving the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula
column7: including by invigorating cooperation in the United Nations Security Council and in law enforcement channels on North Korea
column8: a White House statement said.China is isolated North Korea's most important diplomatic backer and its biggest trading partner.It has been angered by Pyongyang's repeated nuclear and missile tests and signed on to increasingly tough U.N. sanctions
column9: but it has said it believes such steps are not the ultimate answer and called for a return to talks with North Korea.Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi told his Japanese counterpart last week China opposes ""unhelpful"" unilateral sanctions on North Korea but will work within the United Nations to formulate a response.Washington has pressed Beijing to do more to rein in North Korea. The United States has said it is willing to negotiate with the North if the country commits to get rid of its nuclear weapons
column10: which Pyongyang has refused to do.

column1: HONGXIANG PROBE
The U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) is preparing as early as this week to announce legal action against Chinese firms suspected of providing financial assistance to Pyongyang

By Nichola Groom and Valerie Volcovici
| LOS ANGELES/WASHINGTON
LOS ANGELES/WASHINGTONThe 27 states challenging Obama's Clean Power Plan in court say the lower emissions levels it would impose are an undue burden. But most are likely to hit them anyway.Already
column2: Arkansas
column3: North Carolina
column4: Oklahoma and South Dakota appear to be meeting the CPP's early targets. And changes in the power market

column13: say they object to what they view as federal overreach by Obama and the Democrats and want to maintain flexibility to make energy decisions at the state level that reflect changing market conditions.Cynthia Coffman

""That really doesn't factor into my decision to say the federal government has gone beyond its legal authority.""Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt said that he sees the Clean Power Plan as a form of federal ""coercion and commandeering"" of energy policy and that the state should have ""sovereignty to make decisions for its own markets.""The Obama administration finalized the Clean Power Plan in 2015 as a central part of meeting U.S. obligations under the Paris Climate Agreement.In February
column17: the U.S. Supreme Court stayed implementation of the rule pending resolution of the states' litigation. Later this month
column18: a panel of the D.C. Circuit Court is scheduled to hear arguments in the case.The CPP sets carbon-reduction goals for each state
column19: but allows states to decide how to meet them.

column1: During the early years of implementation
column2: the goals are guidelines intended to put states on track to meet the final deadline of 2030. If a state fails to submit a plan to the EPA by interim deadlines
column3: the agency can impose its own plan on that state's power producers. Failure to comply by 2030 could open a state up to administrative penalties and lawsuits.To be sure

column5: which is leading the legal challenge with Texas
column6: still relies largely on carbon-spewing
column7: coal-fired power. And Wisconsin
column9: Montana and Wyoming have large gaps between their current emissions and the plan's mandates.But

column11: the U.S. government's Energy Information Administration earlier this year reduced its forecast for 2030 power plant carbon emissions by nearly 11 percent
column12: without factoring in reductions that may be generated by the Clean Power Plan.The projection for the nation as a whole would be nearly two-thirds of the CPP's target by 2030
column13: even if the law never takes effect.A 2015 analysis by consulting firm M.J. Bradley & Associates for the Environmental Defense Fund found that 21 of the 27 states suing to block the Clean Power Plan are on track to meet its 2024 targets with existing plants and planned investments.

column1: By James Oliphant
| PHILADELPHIA
PHILADELPHIA Democrat Hillary Clinton on Monday accused Republican Donald Trump of aiding Islamic State recruitment
column2: while Trump said she had helped weaken national security as bomb blasts in New York and New Jersey resonated on the U.S. presidential trail.Both candidates for the Nov. 8 election tried to use the weekend attacks to flex their credentials to protect America as world leaders gathered in security-heightened New York for the annual United Nations General Assembly.Clinton said Trump's rhetoric against what he calls ""radical Islamic terrorism"" was helping Islamic State recruit more fighters. ""We know that a lot of the rhetoric we've heard from Donald Trump has been seized on by terrorists

column2: sponsors of the measure said on Monday.Republican Senators Rand Paul and Mike Lee and Democratic Senators Chris Murphy and Al Franken introduced the legislation on Sept. 8.
